hook.text: In 1637 Holland, a single tulip bulb sold for 10 times a craftsman's annual salary. Then prices collapsed.

buildup.text: Tulips arrived in Holland in the 1590s. Rare varieties became status symbols among the wealthy.

discovery.text: Speculators traded tulip futures â€” contracts for bulbs not yet grown. Prices detached from reality.

twist.text: In February 1637, buyers stopped showing up at an auction. Panic spread. Prices fell 90% in days.

climax.text: Tulip mania is often cited as the first recorded speculative bubble. The pattern repeats to this day.

punchline.text: The first bubble was over flowers.

quiz.question: When did Tulip Mania occur?

hook.text: Isaac Newton invested in the South Sea Company, sold for a profit, then bought back in â€” and lost everything.

buildup.text: In 1720, the South Sea Company offered to take over Britain's national debt in exchange for trade monopoly rights.

discovery.text: The stock soared 800% in months as speculation frenzy gripped London. Everyone from servants to lords invested.

twist.text: The company had almost no actual trade revenue. The stock was driven purely by hype and insider manipulation.

climax.text: When the bubble burst, fortunes vanished overnight. Parliament investigated and found massive corruption.

punchline.text: Even Newton couldn't outsmart a bubble.

quiz.question: What was the South Sea Company primarily trading on?
options: Hype and insider manipulation rather than real revenue

hook.text: In 1907, one man â€” J.P. Morgan â€” personally stopped a financial panic. No central bank existed yet.

buildup.text: A failed attempt to corner the copper market triggered a chain of bank runs across New York.

discovery.text: Without a central bank, there was no lender of last resort. Banks couldn't get emergency cash.

twist.text: Morgan locked bankers in his library overnight and refused to let them leave until they agreed to fund a rescue.

climax.text: The crisis led directly to the creation of the Federal Reserve in 1913. One panic built the modern system.

punchline.text: One crisis created America's central bank.

quiz.question: What resulted from the Panic of 1907?
options: The creation of the Federal Reserve

hook.text: In 1720, France's entire economy ran on shares in one company. When it collapsed, the nation nearly followed.

buildup.text: John Law convinced France to back its currency with shares of his Mississippi Company, which held trade rights.

discovery.text: Share prices soared 20-fold. The word 'millionaire' was coined during this bubble.

twist.text: When investors tried to convert shares back to gold, there wasn't enough. The paper wealth was an illusion.

climax.text: The crash was so devastating that France avoided paper money and stock markets for almost a century.

punchline.text: France's trauma lasted generations.

quiz.question: What lasting impact did the Mississippi Bubble have on France?
options: France avoided paper money and stock markets for decades
It created the French stock exchange

hook.text: In the 1840s, Britain built railways everywhere â€” including to towns that didn't need them. Sound familiar?

buildup.text: Railways were the transformative technology of the 1840s. Investors rushed to fund new lines.

discovery.text: Parliament approved 272 railway acts in 1846 alone. Most proposed routes would never generate profit.

twist.text: When reality set in, railway stocks crashed. Thousands of middle-class investors were ruined.

climax.text: But Britain was left with a world-class rail network. The investors lost, but society gained.

punchline.text: Bubbles can build things that last.

quiz.question: What was the lasting outcome of Railway Mania?
options: Britain gained an excellent rail network despite investor losses

hook.text: On October 29, 1929, the stock market lost $14 billion in one day. Fortunes evaporated by lunchtime.

buildup.text: The Roaring Twenties brought massive speculation. People borrowed 90% of stock prices on margin.

discovery.text: When prices dipped, margin calls forced mass selling. Forced selling caused more dips. A death spiral.

twist.text: The crash wasn't the Depression itself. It was the spark. Bad policy responses turned a crash into a catastrophe.

climax.text: The Dow didn't recover to its 1929 peak until 1954 â€” twenty-five years of patient waiting.

punchline.text: One day can reshape an era.

quiz.question: What amplified the stock market crash of 1929?
options: Margin calls forcing mass selling in a downward spiral

hook.text: Rumor spreads: your bank might fail. You rush to withdraw. So does everyone else. Now it actually fails.

buildup.text: In 1930-33, over 9,000 US banks failed. Customers lost savings with no safety net.

discovery.text: Banks keep only a fraction of deposits on hand. If everyone demands money at once, the bank collapses.

twist.text: Bank runs are self-fulfilling prophecies. The fear of failure causes the failure.

climax.text: The FDIC was created in 1933 to insure deposits. Bank runs virtually disappeared in the US afterward.

punchline.text: Deposit insurance ended the self-fulfilling panic.

quiz.question: What stopped bank runs in the United States?
options: The creation of FDIC deposit insurance

hook.text: Economic depression met environmental disaster. Farms blew away as topsoil turned to dust.

buildup.text: Aggressive farming practices stripped the Great Plains of protective grass. Then drought hit.

discovery.text: Dust storms buried towns and destroyed harvests. 2.5 million people fled the Plains states.

twist.text: The Dust Bowl wasn't just a natural disaster. It was an economic one â€” created by bad land incentives.

climax.text: It led to soil conservation programs and showed how economic incentives shape environmental outcomes.

punchline.text: Bad economics can create environmental catastrophe.

quiz.question: What caused the Dust Bowl?
options: Over-farming stripped protective vegetation, then drought hit

hook.text: FDR took office in 1933 and launched the biggest government intervention in American history.

buildup.text: The New Deal created Social Security, the SEC, FDIC, and massive public works programs.

discovery.text: The government hired millions directly. Dams, bridges, and parks built during the New Deal still stand.

twist.text: Economists still debate whether the New Deal ended the Depression â€” or if World War II spending did.

climax.text: Regardless, the New Deal permanently expanded the government's role in the economy and created the safety net.

punchline.text: Crisis reshaped what government could do.

quiz.question: What lasting institution was created by the New Deal?

hook.text: Glass-Steagall separated commercial and investment banking after 1929. It was repealed in 1999. Then 2008 happened.

buildup.text: The Depression taught regulators to separate risky speculation from ordinary banking.

discovery.text: For decades, the separation worked. Banks were boring and safe. The financial system was stable.

twist.text: By the 1990s, stability bred complacency. Banks lobbied to remove restrictions, arguing they were outdated.

climax.text: Within a decade of repeal, the financial system experienced its worst crisis since the Depression.

punchline.text: Forgetting history's lessons invites repetition.

quiz.question: What happened after Glass-Steagall was repealed?
options: The 2008 financial crisis occurred within a decade

hook.text: Inflation hit 14%. Unemployment hit 9%. Economists said both couldn't happen at once. They were wrong.

buildup.text: Stagflation â€” stagnant growth plus high inflation â€” struck the US in the 1970s.

discovery.text: Oil embargoes by OPEC quadrupled energy prices. The cost of everything rose while the economy slowed.

twist.text: Traditional economics said to fight inflation, accept unemployment, or vice versa. Stagflation broke the model.

climax.text: Fed Chair Paul Volcker raised interest rates to 20% in 1981, causing a brutal recession but killing inflation.

punchline.text: Sometimes the cure hurts worse than the disease.

quiz.question: What is stagflation?
options: High inflation combined with stagnant economic growth
Rapid economic growth with low inflation

hook.text: On October 19, 1987, the Dow dropped 22.6% in one day. Still the largest single-day percentage crash ever.

buildup.text: Markets had been rising steadily. Then computerized trading programs triggered automatic sell orders.

discovery.text: Program trading created a feedback loop: selling triggered more selling, which triggered even more.

twist.text: Unlike 1929, the Fed flooded markets with cash immediately. The economy recovered within months.

climax.text: Black Monday led to circuit breakers â€” automatic trading halts when markets fall too fast.

punchline.text: Machines crashed the market. Humans fixed it.

quiz.question: What caused Black Monday's unprecedented crash?
options: Computerized program trading created a selling feedback loop

hook.text: Pets.com had a sock puppet mascot and no profits. It went public, hit $300M valuation, then went bust.

buildup.text: The internet was genuinely revolutionary. But valuations assumed every website would become a giant.

discovery.text: The NASDAQ rose 400% from 1995 to 2000. Companies without revenue had multi-billion dollar valuations.

twist.text: When the bubble burst in 2000, the NASDAQ lost 78% of its value. Trillions in wealth evaporated.

climax.text: The survivors â€” Amazon, Google, eBay â€” proved the internet DID change everything. Just not at 1999 prices.

punchline.text: Right idea, wrong prices, wrong timing.

quiz.question: What was unique about the dot-com bubble?
options: Companies with no revenue had massive valuations based on internet hype
It was caused by government intervention

hook.text: In 1989, Japan's imperial palace grounds were worth more than all California real estate. Then it all crashed.

buildup.text: Japan's asset bubble in stocks and real estate was the largest in modern history.

discovery.text: When the bubble burst in 1990, Japan entered a deflationary spiral that lasted over two decades.

twist.text: Despite zero interest rates, people wouldn't borrow or spend. Deflation made waiting profitable.

climax.text: Japan's Nikkei index didn't recover to its 1989 peak until 2024 â€” thirty-five years later.

punchline.text: Some crashes take a generation to heal.

quiz.question: How long did Japan's economic stagnation last after the bubble burst?

hook.text: In the 1980s, over 1,000 US savings institutions failed. Taxpayers paid $132 billion for the cleanup.

buildup.text: Savings and loans were small banks that took deposits and made home mortgages. Simple and stable.

discovery.text: Deregulation in the 1980s let them make risky bets with insured deposits. Many gambled recklessly.

twist.text: Deposits were federally insured. Executives took huge risks knowing taxpayers would cover the losses.

climax.text: The S&L crisis was a dress rehearsal for 2008 â€” same pattern of deregulation, moral hazard, and bailout.

punchline.text: Insured risk-taking is a recipe for disaster.

quiz.question: What caused the Savings and Loan crisis?
options: Deregulation allowed risky bets with insured deposits

hook.text: Between 2000 and 2006, US home prices doubled. Everyone believed houses only go up. They were wrong.

buildup.text: Low interest rates, loose lending, and speculation drove housing prices to unsustainable levels.

discovery.text: Banks offered no-documentation loans, adjustable rates, and zero-down mortgages to virtually anyone.

twist.text: When adjustable rates reset higher, millions couldn't afford payments. Foreclosures flooded the market.

climax.text: Home prices fell 33% nationally and over 50% in the hardest-hit areas. Millions lost their homes.

punchline.text: Houses don't always go up.

quiz.question: What triggered the wave of mortgage defaults in 2007-2008?
options: Adjustable rate mortgages reset to unaffordable levels

hook.text: Banks bundled thousands of mortgages into securities and sold them. The risk didn't disappear â€” it spread.

buildup.text: Securitization turns illiquid loans into tradeable investments. In theory, it diversifies risk.

discovery.text: Rating agencies gave these bundles AAA ratings â€” the safest possible â€” because housing 'never falls.'

twist.text: The AAA-rated securities were full of subprime loans. When mortgages defaulted, the 'safe' investments imploded.

climax.text: Banks, pension funds, and governments worldwide held these toxic securities. The crisis became global.

punchline.text: Spreading risk everywhere made it everyone's problem.

quiz.question: Why were mortgage-backed securities rated AAA?
options: Agencies assumed housing prices would never decline nationally

hook.text: On September 15, 2008, Lehman Brothers filed for bankruptcy. It was the largest in US history.

buildup.text: Lehman was a 158-year-old investment bank, leveraged 31-to-1 and loaded with mortgage securities.

discovery.text: The government had rescued Bear Stearns months earlier. Markets assumed Lehman would be saved too.

twist.text: The government let Lehman fail. The shock froze global credit markets within hours.

climax.text: Within weeks, governments worldwide were bailing out banks to prevent total economic collapse.

punchline.text: One bank's death nearly killed the system.

quiz.question: What happened when Lehman Brothers was allowed to fail?
options: Global credit markets froze almost immediately

hook.text: The US government spent $700 billion bailing out banks. Critics called it socialism for the rich.

buildup.text: TARP â€” the Troubled Asset Relief Program â€” bought toxic assets and injected capital into failing banks.

discovery.text: The bailouts worked technically. The financial system survived and TARP was eventually repaid with interest.

twist.text: But no major bank executive went to prison. Millions lost homes while bankers kept their bonuses.

climax.text: The unfairness of bailing out those who caused the crisis fueled political anger that reshapes politics today.

punchline.text: The system was saved. Public trust was not.

quiz.question: What was a major criticism of the 2008 bank bailouts?
options: Banks were rescued while homeowners were not
They helped too many small businesses

hook.text: Wall Street recovered by 2013. Many neighborhoods haven't recovered yet. Two different recessions.

buildup.text: The stock market hit new highs within five years. But unemployment, foreclosures, and wage stagnation persisted.

discovery.text: Quantitative easing â€” the Fed buying assets â€” inflated stock and bond prices, benefiting the wealthy.

twist.text: The bottom 50% of Americans own less than 1% of stocks. The recovery passed them entirely.

climax.text: The uneven recovery widened inequality and eroded faith in institutions across the political spectrum.

punchline.text: The market recovered. Many people didn't.

quiz.question: Why did the 2008 recovery feel uneven?
options: Rising asset prices mainly benefited the wealthy
The government gave money to everyone

hook.text: The euro was supposed to unify Europe. In 2010, it nearly tore the continent apart.

buildup.text: After 2008, weak European economies â€” Greece, Ireland, Portugal, Spain â€” couldn't repay their debts.

discovery.text: Sharing a currency meant these countries couldn't devalue to regain competitiveness. They were stuck.

twist.text: Bailout conditions demanded brutal austerity. Greek GDP fell 25%. Youth unemployment hit 60%.

climax.text: The crisis exposed a fundamental flaw: monetary union without fiscal union creates unsolvable imbalances.

punchline.text: Shared currency, unshared burdens.

quiz.question: What structural flaw did the European debt crisis reveal?
options: Monetary union without fiscal union creates imbalances

hook.text: In March 2020, the S&P 500 dropped 34% in 23 trading days. Then it recovered everything in five months.

buildup.text: COVID lockdowns shut down the global economy almost overnight. Markets panicked.

discovery.text: Governments responded with unprecedented stimulus â€” trillions in direct payments, loans, and Fed purchases.

twist.text: The fastest crash became the fastest recovery in history. But the stimulus contributed to persistent inflation.

climax.text: COVID proved that massive fiscal response can prevent depression but isn't free. Inflation is the deferred cost.

punchline.text: The bill for preventing collapse came as inflation.

quiz.question: What was a major side effect of COVID stimulus spending?
options: Persistent inflation in the years following

hook.text: Bitcoin fell from $69,000 to $16,000. FTX, a $32 billion exchange, collapsed in days. Billions vanished.

buildup.text: The 2020-21 crypto boom attracted millions of new investors chasing astronomical returns.

discovery.text: Many projects had no real utility. Stablecoins like TerraUSD turned out to be anything but stable.

twist.text: FTX founder Sam Bankman-Fried was charged with fraud. Customer funds had been secretly gambled away.

climax.text: The crash mirrored classic financial panics: leverage, fraud, herd behavior, and a painful reckoning.

punchline.text: New technology, same old human behavior.

quiz.question: What caused the collapse of FTX?
options: Customer funds were secretly misused and gambled away

hook.text: In March 2023, Silicon Valley Bank collapsed in 48 hours. Twitter accelerated the fastest bank run in history.

buildup.text: SVB held deposits from tech startups and invested heavily in long-term government bonds.

discovery.text: When interest rates rose, those bonds lost value. SVB announced a capital raise. Panic followed.

twist.text: Social media spread fear instantly. Depositors withdrew $42 billion in a single day via smartphone.

climax.text: Regulators stepped in within days. But the speed of a social-media-fueled bank run shocked the system.

punchline.text: Bank runs now happen at the speed of a tweet.

quiz.question: What made the SVB bank run unprecedented?
options: Social media accelerated withdrawals to record speed
It was caused by a cyberattack

hook.text: US inflation hit 9.1% in June 2022 â€” the highest in 40 years. Groceries, gas, and rent all surged.

buildup.text: Trillions in COVID stimulus, supply chain disruptions, and energy shocks collided simultaneously.

discovery.text: Central banks had kept rates at zero for too long, flooding the economy with cheap money.

twist.text: The Fed raised rates at the fastest pace in decades. Mortgage rates doubled. Housing markets froze.

climax.text: The debate continues: was inflation caused by too much spending, supply shocks, or corporate greed?

punchline.text: Inflation returned to remind us it never truly left.

quiz.question: What was the peak US inflation rate in 2022?

hook.text: Every crisis is different. Every crisis is the same. The pattern is boom, denial, panic, and reform.

buildup.text: Economist Hyman Minsky described how stability breeds risk-taking, which breeds instability.

discovery.text: The 'Minsky Moment' is when overleveraged borrowers can no longer cover their debts. Collapse follows.

twist.text: Each generation thinks 'this time is different.' It never is. Human psychology repeats the cycle.

climax.text: Knowing the pattern doesn't prevent it â€” but it can help you prepare personally for the next one.

punchline.text: Stability is destabilizing. That's the paradox.

quiz.question: What is a 'Minsky Moment'?
options: When overleveraged borrowers can no longer service their debts

hook.text: Every major financial law was born from a crisis. We only fix the barn door after the horse escapes.

buildup.text: The SEC was created after 1929. FDIC after bank runs. Dodd-Frank after 2008. Crisis drives reform.

discovery.text: Regulations work â€” for a while. Bank failures dropped to near zero after FDIC insurance.

twist.text: Then industries lobby to weaken rules. Regulations erode until the next crisis proves they were necessary.

climax.text: The cycle of crisis, regulation, complacency, and deregulation has repeated for over 300 years.

punchline.text: We regulate after disaster, then forget why.

quiz.question: What pattern do financial regulations follow?
options: Regulations are never changed once enacted

hook.text: 56% of Americans can't cover a $1,000 emergency. In a crisis, that's the difference between coping and catastrophe.

buildup.text: Crises hit individuals through job loss, reduced hours, medical bills, and falling asset values.

discovery.text: Financial advisors recommend 3-6 months of expenses in easily accessible cash as a buffer.

twist.text: During 2008 and 2020, people with emergency funds avoided forced selling of investments at the worst time.

climax.text: An emergency fund is boring. It earns little. But it buys the most valuable thing in a crisis: time.

punchline.text: Cash reserves buy time when you need it most.

quiz.question: How much do experts recommend keeping in an emergency fund?

hook.text: Enron employees had 62% of their 401(k) in company stock. When it collapsed, their retirement went too.

buildup.text: Diversification means spreading investments across different assets so no single failure ruins you.

discovery.text: A diversified portfolio might include stocks, bonds, real estate, and international holdings.

twist.text: In a crisis, correlations spike. Everything falls together. But diversification still reduces total losses.

climax.text: The investors who survived 2008 best had diversified portfolios AND the discipline not to panic-sell.

punchline.text: Don't put all your eggs in one basket.

quiz.question: Why is diversification important during crises?
options: It reduces total losses even when most assets decline

topics.title: Time in the Market Beats Timing

hook.text: Missing the ten best stock market days over 20 years cuts your return in half. Most happen near crashes.

buildup.text: Market timing means trying to sell before crashes and buy before recoveries. Sounds smart.

discovery.text: Research consistently shows that almost no one â€” professional or amateur â€” can time the market reliably.

twist.text: The biggest up days often occur right after the biggest down days. You have to be in to catch them.

climax.text: A boring, consistent investment strategy through every crisis has outperformed nearly all active strategies.

punchline.text: Stay invested. Time is your edge.

quiz.question: What happens if you miss the ten best market days over 20 years?
options: Your returns are roughly cut in half
